quoteFirst: The forces engaged behaved with great steadiness throughout a trying and unsuccessful night, and at daylight withdrew over open ground without Voormezeele, reaching Dickebush
title: Canada in Flanders, Volume I
author: Beaverbrook, Max Aitken, Baron, 1879-1964

quoteFirst: 4 P.M.—The Sacred Chariot of Her Majesty reached the Summer Palace at
quoteLast: and Their Majesties remained there an hour. Meanwhile, at 6 A.M., Prince Ch’ing, just before starting for the Summer Palace, sent a flag of truce to the Japanese Pigmies who were bombarding the city close to the “Chi Hua” Gate on the east of the city. The gate was thrown open and the troops swarmed in.
title: China under the Empress Dowager
author: Bland, J. O. P. (John Otway Percy), 1863-1945; Backhouse, E. (Edmund), Sir, 1873-1944

quoteFirst: Wheels and horses were splashed with many different colours of mud, as though they had come far and across a considerable diversity of country.  The driver continually and vainly plied his whip.  It seemed to follow they had made a long, perhaps an all-night, stage; and that the driver, at that early hour of
quoteTime: a little after eight in the morning
quoteLast: , already felt himself belated.  I looked for the name of the proprietor on the shaft, and started outright.
title: St. Ives: Being the Adventures of a French Prisoner in England
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis, 1850-1894

quoteLast: , Captain Dobson called down to me, saying that he thought Mr. Kennedy was arrived, as there was a black on shore with a shirt on and trousers.
title:

author: MacGillivray, John, 1822-1867

quoteFirst: We went in order--slowest machines first, at two-minute intervals. I pushed off
quoteLast: , climbed to 2,000 feet and streaked off over the Channel. We had four destroyers at intervals across the Channel in case our engines went wrong, also seaplanes.
title:
In the Royal Naval Air Service
Being the war letters of the late Harold Rosher to his family

quoteFirst: The suburbs of New York are very attractive, and excursions to nearly every point within reach of the city are made every day during the summer months.  The fares are low, and a day may be pleasantly spent on the water by leaving the city
title:
Lights and Shadows of New York Life
or, the Sights and Sensations of the Great City
author: McCabe, James Dabney, 1842-1883

quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , and snowing furiously, and I could scarcely see the outlines of the handsome station through the storm of snow. But it was very comfortable in my compartment, which I was pleased to note was of unusual elegance. So I did not mind the delay at first.
title: The Frontier Boys in the Sierras; Or, The Lost Mine

author: Perelaer, M. T. H. (Michael Theophile Hubert), 1831-1901; Mendes, A. P. [Editor]; Blok, Maurice [Translator]

quoteFirst: They are egg-shaped, with a colourless beak, and as their whole body is bristled with cilia, they leave a long current in their wake when they swim, which they do with such impetus that they are flattened against any obstacle they meet with, even to the discharge of their green endochrome. They escape from their cell
quoteLast: , move for two hours, then come to rest, and begin to grow into a new plant.
title: On Molecular and Microscopic Science, Volume 1 (of 2)
author: Somerville, Mary, 1780-1872

quoteFirst: in connection with a damp atmosphere, had their teeth set chattering. To the northerners, and particularly to the mountaineers among us, there was something suggestive of home in the rolling masses of fog permeated with the balmy odours of the trees and shrubs.
quoteLast: there suddenly sprang up a light warm breeze from the north; the fog broke with magical rapidity, and before us lay, in the brilliant sunshine, a landscape, the overpowering grandeur of which mocks description. Behind us and on our left was the marvellous forest which we had not long since left; right in front of us was a gently sloping stretch of country in which emerald meadows alternated with dark banana-groves and small patches of waving corn.
title: Freeland: A Social Anticipation
author: Hertzka, Theodor, 1845-1924; Ransom, Arthur, 1831-1912 [Translator]

quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , we arrived in the city of Paris, after a pleasant journey of more than three days, through Flanders into France and Paris. After we arrived at Paris we put up our horses, and stopped not either to eat or to drink, but made the best of our way to Passy, about four miles from Paris, where Dr.
title: A Relic of the Revolution
author: Herbert, Charles, 1757-1808

quoteLast: we arrived at the extensive Gambir and pepper plantations, garden, orangery, and neat habitation of a Chinese, who informed us that he had been ten years upon the island. We breakfasted at this place, a servant having been previously sent on with provisions; but we always found the Chinese planters eager to provide us with any provisions they had.
title: Wanderings in New South Wales, Batavia, Pedir Coast, Singapore, and China, Vol. 2 (of 2)
author: Bennett, George, 1804-1893

quoteLast: the exploring party returned with the news that they had found the wreck of the ship _Mozart_ upon the eastern end of the island, that from a slip of paper they had found that she had gone ashore on the 7th of the previous December, and that the supposed sails in the offing were a couple of tents erected for shelter by her crew.
title: Harper's Round Table, January 21, 1896
author: Various

quoteFirst: Rickett's Third Division of the Sixth Corps, the latter officers,--Davis and Chandler,--being from the Tenth Vermont. Here we waited for the enemy to approach. quoteLast: and kept it up till about 5 o'clock p.

quoteFirst: The morning of the 20th broke dark and foggy, but
quoteLast: the weather cleared, and a southerly breeze sprang up.  At a quarter to nine, the southern division weighed, and with a light wind stood towards the batteries, followed shortly afterwards by the _San Martin_ and _Comus_.
title: Our Sailors: Gallant Deeds of the British Navy during Victoria's Reign

quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: . Bishop Jonathan Weaver, who had been secured to dedicate the church, was on the ground for that purpose. When it was learned that the pastor’s wife had passed away, the Bishop and members of the church suggested that the dedicatory services be postponed.
title: The Experiences of Uncle Jack: Being a Biography of Rev. Andrew Jackson Newgent

quoteFirst: And how came it that Napoleon and Ney missed this golden opportunity? In the first case, it was due to their chiefs of staff, who had not sent overnight any tidings as to the results of their respective battles. Until Count Flahaut returned to the Imperial headquarters
quoteLast: , Napoleon knew nothing as to the position of affairs at Quatre Bras; while a similar carelessness on Soult's part left Ney powerless to attempt anything against Wellington until somewhat later in the morning.
title: The Life of Napoleon I (Complete)
author: Rose, J. Holland (John Holland), 1855-1942
